Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Comparative Statics and Dynamic Models

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER award will extend the theory and applications of comparative statics. Monotone comparative statics are central to modern economic analysis. These mathematical methods allow us to build models that can predict how decisions and results react to changes in the economic environment. These methods can be used in dynamic environments to study many important economic problems, including capital growth, the timing of investment decisions, search and experimentation, and dynamic asset pricing.

This project will extend the theory and applications of comparative statics, with a focus on (1) the interplay between comparative statics and dynamic methods, (2) generalizations and applications of the single-crossing property, a mathematical concept that underlies much comparative statics theory, (3) the study of similarity and interdependence between economic decision makers, and (4) a variety of applications. This include applications to political economy, finance, contract theory, and a variety of different search and experimentation models. The research also develops new methods for dynamic modeling that can be used to create new dynamic models that can be analyzed with comparative statics methods as opposed to numerical analysis.

The award also funds multiple educational activities that are designed to make monotone comparative statics methods available to a broader range of social scientists and students. This includes course development, a specialized textbook, and a specialized workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main research output of this period is the production of a 130-page manuscript on monotone comparative statics. One of my main "promises" for this research proposal was the creation of a textbook on the topic.

I will briefly note that "monotone comparative statics" stands for a general, cross sectional methodology to analyze problems in many different fields, from political science to finance, with intensive use in trade economics, networks, and so on. In a nutshell, this methodology aims to describe how optimal or equilibrium decisions change in reaction to modifications in the environment.

There is not textbook on this topic however (except for a book published in 1998, which focuses on somewhat dated methods and contains few applications), and researchers often rely on ad hoc methods. There seems to be high demand for this and I am with with researchers working various fields (e.g., trade, political economy, information economics) to incorporate in the textbook applications and methods that can serve these fields.

More work remains to be done on this book, one of the challenges being that it is a methodological (and mathematical) book aimed at a broad audience. This requires a lot work on organizing the material to increase the difficulty very gradually, and choosing the right set of appliations to appeal to a broad audience.

In addition to the book, I have published several papers last year in top economics journals (2 in Econometrica, 1 in the JPE) which use some comparative static techniques in dynamic contexts. One studies intertemporal preferences for generations that exhibit altruistic concerns towards future geneations. Another concerns a dynamic model in which two parties bargain over contracts and have private information. The third paper concerns the value of commitment to improve over dynamic political equilibria.

Besides these published works, I have been very interested in two topics: judicial mechanism design and institution design. Both topics use the tools of mechanism design, which are themselves strongly related to comparative statics. For example, I show that binary verdicts (acquittal/conviction) emerge as the optimal mechanism of judicial system which also features plea bargaining. (This is not the case for systems without pleas.) The key step in proving this result is based on a comparative statics theorem showing how optimal decisions in statistical decision problems vary with the information structure available to the agent.

With regard to institutional design, I have been interested in the concept of renegotiation, which is at the heart of institutions, and related to this well known problem: what makes a constitution binding? What prevents members of an institution from tearing down their charts and rules when it is convenient to do so? Renegotation is, of course, dynamic in nature, and analyzing it in a general setting also requires the tools of comparative statics. 

Another fact of institution design concerns the enforcement of institutions when the agents in charge of this enforcement may have interests which are misaligned with the institution that they are in charge of protecting. This is, in essence, the question attributed to the Latin poet Juvenal who asked "but who guards the guardians?" and which also lies at the heart of mechanism design. For example, Leonid Hurwicz, often viewed as the father of mechanism design and honored for his work by the 2007 Prize in economics in memory of Alfred Nobel, dedicated a large part of his Nobel lecture to this question. Using the tools of comparative statics, in their interactio with dynamics methods, I study this question and provide a general set of assumptions under which it is impossible to guarantee the integrity of institutions unless their enforcers are ethical (i.e., motivated by goals that lie beyond their personal interests).

Finally, I have recently explored more systematically the role of anticipations and altruism on preferences and their impact on major decisions. For example, I provide a theory (the first, to my knowledge) explaininy why present bias (the phenomenon that human beings tend to be time inconsistent and value commitment to delay gratification) and impatience (the fact that, other things equal, immediate gratification is prefered) should be positively correlated (a fact that has recently been documented empirically).This line of work also relies on comparative statics and dynamic methods. However, it is part of a broader, distinct project which aims to understand better intertemporal and altruistic preferences. (This part is, in fact, the subject of a new NSF proposal which I submitted in Januarywith Simone Galperti.)
